title: 104_hr3434
content: The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" limits representation or advising of certain foreign entities. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" restricts former officers or employees from representing foreign entities within 10 years of their service termination. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" imposes penalties on former officers or employees who represent foreign entities within 5 years of their service termination. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" imposes penalties on individuals or entities with ties to the United States who engage in representation for foreign entities within 5 years of their service termination. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" imposes penalties on individuals with ties to the United States who provide representation or advice to foreign entities related to US matters. The restrictions apply to the President and individuals subject to specific subsections. The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" imposes penalties on individuals with ties to the United States who provide representation or advice to foreign entities related to US matters. Definitions for terms like 'compensation', 'government of a foreign country', and 'foreign political party' are provided in subsection (c), (d), or (e). The "Revolving Door Act of 1996" defines terms like 'United States', 'State', and sets the effective date of the amendment to January 1, 1997. The amendment made by subsection (a) takes effect on January 1, 1997 and does not apply to individuals whose service ended before that date. SEC. 3. CROSS-OVER LOBBYING. The amendment to Section 207(d) of title 18, United States Code imposes additional restrictions on former executive branch officers or employees who knowingly attempt to influence members of Congress or legislative branch employees within 1 year of leaving their government position. The amendment to Section 207(e) of title 18, United States Code adds an additional restriction on former Members of Congress and employees of the legislative branch who had salaries exceeding 120 percent of the minimum rate of basic pay for GS-15. The amendment to Section 207(e) of title 18, United States Code imposes restrictions on former Members of Congress and legislative branch employees with salaries exceeding 120 percent of the minimum rate of basic pay for GS-15. It prohibits them from making communications or appearances before executive branch officers or employees on behalf of any other person, with intent to influence. SEC. 4. FELONS. Section 207 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to prohibit convicted felons who are former Members of Congress, former high-salary employees of the House or Senate, or certain executive branch employees from making any compensated communication or appearance before House employees. Convicted felons who are former Members of Congress, former high-salary employees of the House or Senate, or certain executive branch employees are prohibited from making any compensated communication or appearance before House employees. SEC. 5 amends the Foreign Agents Registration Act regarding lobbying activities. SEC. 6 addresses civil penalties. SEC. 6 of the Foreign Agents Registration Act introduces civil penalties of up to $50,000 for each violation knowingly committed.
